thread.title: Kenya: KQ Boss Says KLM Pact Not Profitable
thread.title_full: Kenya: KQ Boss Says KLM Pact Not Profitable

title: Kenya: KQ Boss Says KLM Pact Not Profitable
text:
Liberia: Highway Casualties Confirmed - 68 Commuters - 30 Hurt - 6 Dead 
He said the partnership led to a plunge in the number of travellers for the insolvent KQ due to the shared routes. 
Nguze appeared before the select committee of the Senate chaired by Kisumu senator Anyang' Nyong'o which is investigating the problems facing the carrier 
Ngunze said that although they had failed to make any profits, the partnership protected the company from feeling the effects of the losses. 
"With the deterioration in numbers in the route we have made a loss in the joint venture on the trunk route. In the context of the revenues and the cost on the route we share 50/50 and over the last three years the route has been loss-making. However, KQ has been paid a settlement out of there. Because of the agreement we have, we get a cash settlement because of the balance in transaction," Ngunze said 
A section of leaders and shareholders have been asking for the reconsideration of the agreement saying it had contributed towards the massive losses. 
The CEO told the committee that they have been struggling to get travellers in Europe because of the travel advisories that have affected the number of tourists coming to Kenya. 
Most European countries issued travel advices to their citizens planning to visit Kenya following a spate of terrorist attacks by Somalia-based terrorist group al Shabaab over the last five years. 
The CEO was also questioned by the lawmakers over the closing of some flight paths soon after they were launched. 
"It is not unusual in aviation industry to start routes and stop them. It is not abnormal. In the last one year we close Abu Dhabi, New Delhi and Bangui. We suspended Freetown and Monrovia because of the travel restrictions," Ngunze said. Kenya
